Nagashizzar, which means "Glory of Nagash" in High Nehekharan, known also as the Cursed Pit.
The warpstone mines beneath Nagashizzar form a huge honeycomb of galleries and mineshafts, patrolled by untiring sentries from Nagash's Undead legions.
Four mighty gates guard the approaches to Nagashizzar, made from a nameless black metal which shines like burning obsidian and is ten times harder than steel.

Within his audience chamber at the height of the peak, Nagash sits on his throne of skulls. He has brooded here for over a millennium, waiting, and planning, guiding his agents by the power of his thoughts.
Nagashizzar, the Black City, is one of the mightiest fortresses the world has ever seen, excavated from the living rock of Cripple Peak.
Colossal sheets of stone laden with the corpses of those long gone are layered in concentric rings that protect this cold accursed place.
A singular entrance, a great but crumbling stone gateway taking the form of a skull, stands imposing, watching over the steps below.
Deep under the city's ruins lies the barrow of King Alcadizaar, the slayer of Nagash; his spirit is chained to the very stone of the surrounding city for all eternity.
A crude black marble pyramid sits above King Alcadizzars barrow, once home to Kadon the Eternal, and The Cult of Nagash.
The city of Mourkain, translates literally in the tongue of its founder to mean Place of Death.
The once great city has been left completely in ruins, a shell of its former glory.

The Hall of Rebirth that surrounds the palaceâ€™s grand royal gardens, creates an illusion of tamed wilderness and beauty; brilliantly coloured songbirds fill the space with serenity, discretely hiding a chilling laughter of cruelty.

Queen Neferata rules over her Lahmian sisterhood from here, enacting out her plots and machinations from finding lost items, devotees among the nobility, deluded pawns and lovers who can be used to rebuild Lahmia.

The Temple of Blood is a fortress within a fortress. Situated within the walls of the Lahmian royal palace. Its single entrance sealed with a pair of immense bronze doors and guards the home of The Cult of Blood.
The City of the Dawn, home to the first of the Vampires, restored through blood to be a beacon of lethal beauty.
At the center of the city, thousands of pyramids form a gigantic labyrinth, each of them at least several hundred feet tall.
The once great inscription that adorned the Obelisk of Khemri has been reduced a single legible phrase "let none dare oppose my will!"
The Temple of the Sun is located deep within the Necropolis of Khemri; Mystical invocations are used here to raise Carrion birds from death, to fight the enemies of Khemri and now Nagash.
Within this ivory edifice, Nehekhara's fearsome legions await a king's command, standing ready to march to war and destroy his enemies.
Khemri, the City of Kings, is the jewel in the crown of Nehekhara.
This hulking port sits at the mouth of the Great Ocean. Any who cross these seas risk encounters of the dead kind.
A ring of sodden cannons sits atop imposing battlements, no matter the approach from land or sea; all are caught in the "dead zones".
A vast floating graveyard, wooden hulls left to decay and rot; yet the wrecks can be brought to battle at the sirens calls.
Deep within the city lies a haul like no other, treasures from each corner of the world and riches unkown.
The City of Reawakening, a name it intends to live up to, and with the help of the Dhar-infused star chamber at the center of the city, it surely will.
Beneath the gigantic central keep are a huge number of crypts and dungeons, filled to the brim with huma cattle.
Inside the Scarlet Library is rumored to be a treasure trove of occult lore. It is said that copies of all the great sorcerous works can be found there.
The Court Hall are where the Undead nobles, and living thralls come to play games of courtly intrigue.
Castle Drakenhof is built on the Drakenfelsen, the former lair of a large dragon from which Drakenhof gained its name.
Castle Drakenhof, the Accursed Citadel, is the sprawling ancestral fortress of the von Carstein bloodline. Ever since the coming of Vlad, it has been the de facto political center of Sylvania.
Titanic walls of jagged obsidian protrude from its mountainous landscape, a defensive position like no other.
The catacombs of this impossibly ancient city conceal treasures that are not of this realm.
Quintex has stood since before the dawn of recorded history. Within its vaults lie treasures beyond comprehension.
The deepest chancels within Quintex may very well hold treasures and learnings that unlock the past, and foretell the future.
Quintex, the Ancient City, origins unknown, this bastion has witnessed the rise and fall of countless civilizations and will likely see many more fall still.
A colossal black tower of carved obsidian pierces through the landscape with a shrouded dark aura puzzling at its base.
The ground has split in two, a chilling wind gushes into the chasm, ferrying a stream of souls to its depths.
Legions of ancient warriors encased behind grand carved stones, waiting to hear their call to battle.
Underneath these sandstone tombs lay the vast dorment armies of Nehekhara.
Glory of Nagash, forever and always.
Hear the siren's call, as the dead are calling.
No pulse, no breath, no life, yet still they stir.
Warpstone is Nagash's most valuable resource and he will strip the earth bare to get it all.
Unstable footing accompanied by a mysterious crunching sound...
There are some places in the world where no living thing should tread.
Obscured behind chocking mists, a vast grasping bog that saps the energy for all who venture through it.
Dont get too close now, you might just lose your soul.
Many a rider has lost their steed in the treacherous drifting sands. The corpses still litter the fast-holding mires.
Countless soldiers have fallen in battle. They will all rise again to serve and fight under Nagash
Next to every great temple of the Mortuary Cult lies a covered pit in which its deadly, ophic guardians dwell.
Great beasts of burden and horrors of the desert, broken and made to serve their Undead masters.
The crack of cartilage, the snap, the whine, and the howls of delight define the Bonemaster's work.
The gleaming carriages of the Nehekharan chariots shine with the power of the brassworker's mastery.
What better ammunition for catapults than the flaming, screaming skulls of the defeated dead?
Dread towers tower high and cast chilling darkness over the landscape.
Interred in resplendent and decadent tombs, ancient Nehekharans lie in repose until their master calls them hence.
From these death houses, the dead continue to rise to fulfil their as-yet unfinished duty.
Once tombs of those with noble blood, they have been awakened to pursue their living aspirations once more.
Vast chambers of worked and preserved bone provide the perfect sanctuary for the resting dead.
In the once-resplendent streets of these crumbling cities, the dead shuffle about their business as if nothing has changed.
Death is more than a business now, it is life itself!
Crumbling edifices flank the streets of these once great cities; monuments to those who came before replaced by a single figure.
Those consigned to another world, revived to an insipid parody of life to do their master's bidding.
Interred at their liege lord's request, these soldiers are ready to fight again at a moment's notice.
The Tomb Kings demanded loyalty from their soldiers until death and beyond. In Unlife, they expect the same, and so does Nagash.
The abominable Necrosphinx towers above the Nehekharans, offering protection and destruction in exchange for hushed and cowed adoration.
It is not the sting of the Scorpion that kills, but rather its powerful claws and voracious, insatiable appetite.
The ushabti guard of Nagash's inner sanctum, the Sepulchrex responded only to Nagash's will.
Sepulchrex are adorned with the graven images of the gods Nagash has cast down, reminders of cherished victories.
The heat-bleached bone warriors of grim countenance watch over the battlements, watching for foes through hollowed sockets.
These lithified walls have seen empires rise and fall, and endured the accession of doom. They hold.
The hieroglyphics inscribed upon these battlements channel protective wards, fending off any would-be invaders.
The might of the Khemrian Warsphinx stands astride the cities of the dead, roaring eternally.
Each necropolis, has a temple dedicated to Nehekhara's Mortuary Cult. Here reside the Liche Priests served by many lesser priests.
The wording of each and every incantation is recorded on dusty papyrus scrolls written in the mysterious hieroglyphs of Nehekhara's ancient language.
The crypts of this world are dangerous places, the dead do not rest here, they do not rest.
To summon vile minions, a circle must be etched in the ground, with symbols of a dead language scrawled around it.
An infernal lodestone is planted inside a binding circle, summoning the most powerful of all spirits as it glows.
A swirling mass of dark energy swarms around the site, tearing a gateway in the sky to the Realm of Souls.
Gem mines are valuable resources, especially if they have a high yield.
Precious gems are said to capture the eyes, minds and hearts of the living, so maybe their souls too.
The opulence of the unliving knows no bounds and requires magnificent stones to be unearthed in ever-increasing amounts...
Volcanic ore is quite rare, and a precious resource for Nagash due to the way it can interact with certain magic lores.
Items, such as talismans, made from obsidian often hold arcane power, it is this reason that Nagash uses it to build his strongholds.
To be skilled at carving obsidian is to be skilled in sigils and symbols of power, for obsidian soaks in the ensorcelled.
Deep in the red pits can be found mercury in the raw form of cinnabar. A material often used in Dark Magic rituals.
The Blood Mines are red as cinnabar - and occasionally Warpstone - are found here in significant seams.
Best not choose the dark green powder, though, it certainly isn't snuff!
To hunt here is to become the hunted, for the prey is vicious and probably dead alreadyâ€¦
Should the dead be commanded to, an expedition will venture into the haunted woods in search of beasts to be killed, then promptly unkilled.
What is the Flayer? A myth, but one that is all too real.
Gold found here is always tarnished and far from the pure element so beloved by Dwarfs. Nevertheless, it has value.
When Nagash's legions discover a large seam of gold, they will send their minions forth to scour it clean.
A great furnace with an ornate, brazen face, and yellow-green balefire within its sneering mouth.
The blackest iron ore can be found in the deepest pits, underneath the mountains upon which gothic castles perch.
Since before the building of Nagashizzar, Necromancers have used Zombies & Ghouls to burrow and mine mountains for their minerals.
Cursed iron ore is laced with Warpstone. Such mines are prized.
The dread castles of Nagash are made from stone shaped by the dead themselves.
There is an art to creating a memorable tombstone or grand mausoleum.
Some gargoyles are fashioned by sculptors - others just appear, as if they flew there themselves.
Beneath the blood-clotted streams and rank sewage are pits of dense, dark clay.
Using the raw clay compound, urn makers create opulent vessels to carry the ashes of powerful beings.
Perhaps there is some spirit trapped within, burning in abject agony every time the kilns are lit?
Stagnant ponds can be found by their disgusting reek, the brackish water full of brine and other thingsâ€¦
The only thing that rises from these crumbling salt marshes are bony hands reaching toward the sky.
Deep in the dead marches are salt pans, containing piles and piles of bones, bleached and scoured white.
Foresting in Hunger Wood or the Spider Haunts is surely a fool's job?
Once part of a burgeoning timber industry, the sawmills have remained in a ruined, yet operational state since...
From the ruined sawmills, Zombie bearers transport their cursed loads to large sheds long-thought abandoned by mortals.
When a Vampire drinks an "aged red" from a wine glass, chances are it hasn't been made from grapesâ€¦
These orchards contain low-hanging, spooky trees, whose thorny branches are as likely to grab a passer-by as provide fruit.
Vampires crave the illusion that they are nobles, and so they bottle their own "special" vintages.
Once a living settlement of living creatures, now little more than magic-scorched cold ruins where the unliving roam and march.
Nagash cares little about seafaring, but he understands strategic locations. These can turn out useful to Harkon, on good days.
Oh, what a victory to be savoured, and many monuments to be defaced.
